Police Dog Hogan play Ipswich County Library

Oct 6, 2015 • Leon Paternoster

After a summer playing festivals including Port Eliot, Cornbury and Larmer Tree, and a year that saw airplay on Radio 2, BBC 6Music, BBC Scotland, BBC London and BBC Wales, Police Dog Hogan are back on the road with a string of live dates for late 2015 and early 2016.

The band play Ipswich County Library on Saturday 7 November, and will be supported by local duo Honey and the Bear.

Tickets available from Ipswich County Library or buy tickets online. Doors 7.30 for 8.00 start.

There are 8 members in the line-up, including the Guardian’s Tim Dowling, who often writes about their gigs and the ‘band that I’m in’. Instruments include guitar, accordion, banjo, mandolin, fiddle and trumpet.

Police Dog Hogan draw their influences from many different wells. You could call their music Americana, country-folk or even urban bluegrass, but it’s difficult to do justice to the sheer range of styles this band can bend to its will.

Their most recent CD, the uniformly well-received Westward Ho!, was praised for its “wit, passion, eccentricity and unrelenting excellence”. Their live shows are no less passionate or unrelenting. “At Maverick they huffed and puffed and blew the house down, leaving a trail of destruction in their wake,” said Louise Rogers of Americana UK.

Praise for Westward Ho!

“…an intelligence and maturity behind the songs here… bold infectious and affecting” – R2 Magazine

“Westward Ho! is great – a true love story to the British south west and full of hugely enjoyable and fun folk rock tunes.” – digital fix

“Terrific lyrics.” – Whispering Bob Harris

“Fantastic song-writing and top musicians” – Folk Radio UK

“Even better and easier on the ear than their previous offering, Land of Miracles… I can’t stop myself singing along.” – No Depression
